image.altText: A woman walks past "vote yes" and "vote no" signs on a fence.

items.synopsis: The nation is bound for the ballot box today to cast their vote in a referendum that could shape the country for generations to come — but the path to this poll has been a rocky one.

title.children: It once seemed unlikely to ever happen, but today Australians will vote on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament

image.altText: An aerial view shows a crowded roundabout.

items.synopsis: Foreign Minister Penny Wong urges Australians who are in Israel or the Palestinian territories and intend to leave to do so as soon as they can. Follow live.

title.children: Twenty Australians are trying to leave Gaza chaos as ground invasion looms, Penny Wong says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Foreign Minister Penny Wong has urged Australians who are in Israel or the Palestinian territories and intend to leave to do so as soon as they can. Speaking in Adelaide, Senator Wong said about 825 Australians have so far left Israel and the Palestinian territories, but about 20 Australians are still seeking to leave Gaza. She also confirmed a second repatriation flight will arrive in Tel Aviv today to bring Australians to Dubai. "If you wish to leave, please do not delay … Please take the first available flight. Please do not wait for another option," she said. "I would emphasise that the situation on the ground is changing quickly, it is extremely difficult." Senator Wong said Australians still in Israel or the Palestinian territories should register with the DFAT crisis portal or call the government's 24-hour consular emergency centre on +61 2 6261 3305 for assistance.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Foreign minister says 20 Australians seeking to leave Gaza

children.content: Foreign Minister Penny Wong has urged Australians who are in Israel or the Palestinian territories and intend to leave to do so as soon as they can.
Speaking in Adelaide, Senator Wong said about 825 Australians have so far left Israel and the Palestinian territories, but about 20 Australians are still seeking to leave Gaza.
She also confirmed a second repatriation flight will arrive in Tel Aviv today to bring Australians to Dubai.

props.alt: A middle-aged woman with short grey hair looks serious as she speaks in front of a row of "Vote Yes" placards.

children.content: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the situation in Israel is extremely difficult.
(ABC News)
"If you wish to leave, please do not delay … Please take the first available flight. Please do not wait for another option," she said.
"I would emphasise that the situation on the ground is changing quickly, it is extremely difficult."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The first of several flights carrying Australians out of Israel has arrived safely in London after leaving Tel Aviv's Ben Gurion Airport on Friday afternoon local time. The flight contained 238 passengers. Qantas also has another flight planned for Sunday, and two charter flights have also been arranged. Speaking ahead of the flight's arrival, Australia's high commissioner to the UK, Stephen Smith, said: "It's always great, as an Australian official, to help people out of harm's way." The ABC's Mitch Woolnough was at the airport in Tel Aviv to cover the flight's departure, and took these snaps.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian repatriation flight lands safely in London

children.content: The first of several flights carrying Australians out of Israel has arrived safely in London after leaving Tel Aviv's Ben Gurion Airport on Friday afternoon local time.
The flight contained 238 passengers. Qantas also has another flight planned for Sunday, and two charter flights have also been arranged.
Speaking ahead of the flight's arrival, Australia's high commissioner to the UK, Stephen Smith, said: "It's always great, as an Australian official, to help people out of harm's way."
The ABC's
Mitch Woolnough
was at the airport in Tel Aviv to cover the flight's departure, and took these snaps.

props.alt: Several young people with luggage, seen speaking near an Australian flag

children.content: People at Ben Gurion Airport prepare to check in for the Qantas flight.
(ABC News: Mitch Woolnough)

props.alt: A person wearing a vest saying Australian Official, seen from behind

children.content: An Australian official helps direct people fleeing Israel yesterday at Tel Aviv airport.
(ABC News: Mitch Woolnough)

props.alt: A man speaking to two people sitting behind a desk.

children.content: A man prepares to check in for the Qantas flight to London.
(ABC News: Mitch Woolnough)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's just gone past midnight in Israel, meaning the IDF's deadline for civilians to evacuate northern Gaza has passed. Médecins Sans Frontières (Doctors Without Borders) is reporting that the deadline issued to the Al Awda Hospital in Nuseirat refugee camp to evacuate by midnight alongside the rest of the population has been extended to 6am. "The evacuation of patients remains complicated," MSF said in a tweet. Meanwhile, CNN is reporting that US President Joe Biden gave a one-word answer when asked what worried him about a ground invasion of Gaza: "Death." The president was speaking with attendees after delivering a speech on the US economy in Philadelphia on Friday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Midnight deadline passes, Biden fears civilian deaths

children.content: It's just gone past midnight in Israel, meaning the IDF's deadline for civilians to evacuate northern Gaza has passed.

Médecins Sans Frontières (Doctors Without Borders) is reporting that the deadline issued to the Al Awda Hospital in Nuseirat refugee camp to evacuate by midnight alongside the rest of the population has been extended to 6am.
"The evacuation of patients remains complicated," MSF said in a tweet.
Meanwhile, CNN is reporting that US President Joe Biden gave a one-word answer when asked what worried him about a ground invasion of Gaza: "Death."
The president was speaking with attendees after delivering a speech on the US economy in Philadelphia on Friday.

image.altText: People lining up on a footpath to enter a voting centre. Cars parked nearby, and a Voting Centre sign on the footpath

items.synopsis: Australians across the country are heading to the polls to vote in the Voice to Parliament referendum. Follow our live blog for the latest updates.

title.children: Australians head to the polls to cast their vote in Voice to Parliament referendum

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Charlotte Gore In a press conference at Old Parliament House in Canberra, Australian Electoral Commissioner Tony Rogers has made a last-ditch attempt to quash what he called "nonsense" misinformation on the Voice. He said he has been shocked at the "bizarre" and "nutty" conspiracy theories surrounding the ballot. "We run one of the most transparent voting systems in the world," he said. "A hundred thousand members of the community, who are the eyes and the ears of the community — thousands of scrutineers who watch everything that we do. "And please, if you've got a question ask a member of the AEC – don't believe that nonsense online." Mr Rodgers said whether the result of the referendum is known tonight will depend on how close the outcome is. "If there is a very large margin, we'll know the results of that this evening," he said. "[But] we've had something like 2 million postal vote applications – those votes have to come back before we can count them." Lines have formed outside polling booths across Canberra this morning, with two thirds of Canberrans expected to cast their votes in person today. About 119,000 Canberrans – or just over a third – have already pre-polled, in addition to the 25,000 that applied for a postal vote.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Electoral Commission chief calls out 'bizarre' and 'nutty' conspiracy theories

props.alt: A man in glasses and an AEC vest speaks in front of voting booths

children.content: (ABC News: Ian Cutmore)
Reporting by Charlotte Gore
In a press conference at Old Parliament House in Canberra, Australian Electoral Commissioner Tony Rogers has made a last-ditch attempt to quash what he called "nonsense" misinformation on the Voice.
He said he has been shocked at the "bizarre" and "nutty" conspiracy theories surrounding the ballot.
"We run one of the most transparent voting systems in the world," he said.
"A hundred thousand members of the community, who are the eyes and the ears of the community — thousands of scrutineers who watch everything that we do.
"And please, if you've got a question ask a member of the AEC – don't believe that nonsense online."
Mr Rodgers said whether the result of the referendum is known tonight will depend on how close the outcome is.
"If there is a very large margin, we'll know the results of that this evening," he said.
"[But] we've had something like 2 million postal vote applications – those votes have to come back before we can count them."

props.alt: The stairs of Old Parliament House in Canberra, where a Voting Centre sign sits at the front door

children.content: (ABC News: Anthea Moodie)
Lines have formed outside polling booths across Canberra this morning, with two thirds of Canberrans expected to cast their votes in person today.
About 119,000 Canberrans – or just over a third – have already pre-polled, in addition to the 25,000 that applied for a postal vote.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the No campaign has been stoking division. "The No campaign has spoken about division while stoking it," he said in Sydney. "I tell you what division represents in this country — division is the division between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians. "That sees just four out of the 19 Closing the Gap targets being on track to be achieved. We must do better. We can do better. "This is not a radical proposition. This is a hand outstretched of friendship from the First Australians to every Australian, just asking for it to be grasped in that spirit of reconciliation and friendship. "There has been a lot of nonsense said over recent months during this campaign and the fact that the No campaign wants to talk about everything but what is on the ballot paper says that there is no legitimate critique of what people are actually voting for, and I remind Australians who have not yet voted to read what the constitutional change proposed is."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM says No campaign has stoked division

props.alt: A man speaking in a hat and glasses outside , with other men behind him

children.content: (ABC News)
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the No campaign has been stoking division.
"The No campaign has spoken about division while stoking it," he said in Sydney.
"I tell you what division represents in this country — division is the division between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians.
"That sees just four out of the 19 Closing the Gap targets being on track to be achieved. We must do better. We can do better.

"This is not a radical proposition. This is a hand outstretched of friendship from the First Australians to every Australian, just asking for it to be grasped in that spirit of reconciliation and friendship.

"There has been a lot of nonsense said over recent months during this campaign and the fact that the No campaign wants to talk about everything but what is on the ballot paper says that there is no legitimate critique of what people are actually voting for, and I remind Australians who have not yet voted to read what the constitutional change proposed is."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What are the lasting effects of the Voice Referendum? Whether it gets up, or fails to pass, the fallout from this campaign will be felt long after. How is it playing out for Indigenous people now? And what impact will it have on our international reputation? In the final weeks before the Referendum, ABC's Carly Williams and Fran Kelly discuss what the outcome will mean for Australians beyond the vote. You can watch the video below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What will change after the Voice referendum?

children.content: What are the lasting effects of the Voice Referendum? Whether it gets up, or fails to pass, the fallout from this campaign will be felt long after. How is it playing out for Indigenous people now? And what impact will it have on our international reputation? In the final weeks before the Referendum,
ABC's Carly Williams and Fran Kelly discuss what the outcome will mean for Australians beyond the vote.
You can watch the video below.

image.altText: In the golden light of a dusty evening, is a silhouette of man in hat on horseback leading cattle.

items.synopsis: Bullo River Station on the edge of the east Kimberley is a cattle station with its gaze firmly fixed on nature. Working with the Australian Wildlife Conservancy, they are demonstrating conservation and pastoral activities can coexist.

title.children: As a place for big dreams, this Kimberley cattle station shows how conservation and pastoral goals can combine

image.altText: A person in a crowd holds up a sign with the Aboriginal flag and the words "Voice to Parliament".

items.synopsis: A No vote — and how we got to one — will change the way we see ourselves, and send the most unloving of messages to Indigenous Australians, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: The public sentiment shift that turned the tide of the Voice referendum

image.altText: Three posters with photographs of people and the words 'bring them home'

items.synopsis: A week after Hamas terrorists' brutal attack on Israel, up to 150 kidnap victims remain in Gaza. Experts on hostage negotiation and terrorism say the world now faces several difficult choices.

title.children: The world's never seen a hostage crisis quite like this. Here's how it could play out

image.altText: A sullen man looks into the camera.

items.synopsis: There was a time when the name of one whistleblower was on everyone's lips. Kathy Jackson was lauded as a "revolutionary" — but in the shadows was another person waiting to blow the whistle on her.

title.children: The whistleblower who captured the nation — and the man who unmasked her as a fraud

image.altText: Israeli soldiers walk on grassy terrain.

items.synopsis: Israel says its infantry and tanks have carried out raids inside the Gaza Strip, its first announcement of a shift from an air war to ground operations to root out Hamas militants a week after their deadly rampage in southern Israel.

title.children: Israeli military says troops have made their first ground raids into Gaza

image.altText: A woman sobs as people stand against a sandstone wall at a funeral

items.synopsis: Israel is preparing to carry out a ground operation whose mission is to "destroy Hamas". But what then? What is the political reality and make-up of Gaza and what would it look like without Hamas, asks John Lyons.

title.children: 'Israel now will not stop': One week into war and a dangerous political reality has set in

image.altText: Costa, who has long hair and a bushy beard, smiles against a blue backdrop, with images of a cheese toastie and kimchi.

items.synopsis: If we're being honest, Costa's known for one thing: the delightfully enormous beard covering half his face. We sat down with the Gardening Australia host to find out if his big beard really is full of secrets.

title.children: Eating burgers with a knife and fork and even killing houseplants: Costa reveals his darkest secrets

image.altText: Victoria Beckham and David Beckham pose for a photo, wearing suits, in front of a Netflix media wall

items.synopsis: The Posh and Becks story is a distortion of the Cinderella legend, as triumph isn't the result of noblesse oblige, of being selected, but the result of middle class striving that Britain has long struggled to understand, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: As Posh and Becks became more successful, the invisible class wall was always there

image.altText: A woman, a man and two young children look at the camera, surrounded by luggage and other people

items.synopsis: Tal Raymond, Dana Elhadad and their two young children were among the first Australians at Tel Aviv's Ben Gurion Airport for a Qantas repatriation flight on Friday, but not all of them got on board.

title.children: 'Hardest decision I've ever had to make': Aussie families torn apart at Tel Aviv airport

image.altText: composite of fire truck for western australia fire service, people at a beach side pool in sydney and people skiing in perisher

items.synopsis: A quick glance at the national forecast this weekend and you could be forgiven for questioning what season we're in. ABC meteorologist Tom Saunders explains what is driving the country's weather disparity.

title.children: Heat in the west and snow in the south-east — here's what is driving Australia's stark weather contrasts

image.altText: England's Ollie Watkins slides in to score a goal against the Socceroos.

items.synopsis: The Socceroos are unable to replicate the famous upset win from 20 years ago, going down 1-0 after a second-half Ollie Watkins strike.

title.children: Socceroos go down to England in Wembley friendly

image.altText: Haiti's President Jovenel Moïse leaves a museum

items.synopsis: In 2021, a doctor and pastor met with his friends in Florida allegedly to arrange the overthrow of the Haitian president. Now Kenya is being sent in to help a country plunged into chaos.

title.children: How a group of Florida men allegedly plotted the assassination of the Haitian president and sent the country into chaos

image.altText: A composite photo of Ramia Abdo Sultan, left, and Tzipi Cohen Hyams, both looking serious

items.synopsis: Many Israeli and Palestinian people in Australia know someone who has either been killed, injured, kidnapped, displaced, or is in hiding. As the conflict escalates, they fear more bad news.

title.children: 'I fear what's going to happen next': Israelis and Palestinians in Australia reflect on the week that changed everything

image.altText: A man wearing a suit sits on a stool surrounded by TV camera and lights.

items.synopsis: Anxiety about coming out. Name calling. Feeling you can't be your true self at work. Three LGBTQIA+ journalists discuss some of the hurdles they've experienced in their careers.

title.children: A journalist threatened to out Anton Enus. This is what happened

image.altText: Australasian College for Emergency Medicine NT chair Dr Stephen Gourley profile shot.

items.synopsis: Stephen Gourley says the Voice to Parliament is key for meaningful reconciliation that will improve the lives of Indigenous people who suffer with "diseases of poverty".

title.children: Voice vital to reconciliation, improved Indigenous health outcomes, says chief emergency doctor

image.altText: an aboriginal couple with a little baby

items.synopsis: A Northern Territory family with a one-month-old baby say they have spent weeks living in a public house overrun with sewage, despite repeated calls for help.

title.children: Remote NT family fear baby will fall ill due to 'disgusting' housing conditions

image.altText: Marie Piccone looking at mangoes

items.synopsis: It has taken decades of work and a number of setbacks, but three mango varieties are being commercially rolled out — and finally have names.

title.children: Yess! AhHa! Now! New names, new varieties of mango in supermarkets after years of development

image.altText: A group of emperor penguins and their chicks standing on a snowy landscape in Antarctica.

items.synopsis: A deadly strain of bird flu that has already killed millions of seabirds across the world is likely to land on Antarctic shores this summer, threatening already struggling penguin colonies and marine mammals.

title.children: 'We can't stop it': Bird flu strain that has devastated seabirds worldwide will likely reach Antarctica this year

image.altText: A young woman gazes at a magenta flower

items.synopsis: When Lauren Bouyer tries to conjure an image in her mind's eye, nothing happens. Researchers say her condition, aphantasia, is more prevalent than previously thought.

title.children: Loren can't 'see' things in her imagination. It's more common than you might think

image.altText: US representative Jim Jordan surrounded by journalists holding out phones and microphones

items.synopsis: Republicans in the US House of Representatives have nominated hardline conservative Jim Jordan to lead the chamber, but he must still win majority on the House floor. Republican infighting has left the House at a deadlock for 10 days as war ramps up in the Middle East.

title.children: US House Republicans nominate Jim Jordan for speaker, testing hardline appeal

image.altText: A Cruise driverless taxi in San Francisco

items.synopsis: A recent Californian trial saw self-driving taxis crash into a fire truck and get bogged in wet cement. Such incidents erode trust in the technology, writes autonomous systems researcher Zena Assaad.

title.children: San Francisco's driverless taxis marked a new era in transportation. Then the problems started

image.altText: Sensors sit next to a tablet with weather information

items.synopsis: Queensland researchers launch a project to develop an in-home early warning system for elderly residents during extreme heat.

title.children: Heat kills more people in Australia than any other natural disasters. These researches are looking at a simple solution

image.altText: A range of old cars in a car museum.

items.synopsis: Experts believe the future of vehicles will include a mix of technologies as the planet becomes more environmentally conscious.

title.children: As the world becomes more environmentally conscious, what does this mean for classic and prestige car lovers?

image.altText: Rescue workers standing together after a knife attack.

items.synopsis: A man who had been under surveillance as a potential security threat attacked a teacher days after he was questioned by French intelligence services over suspicions of Islamic radicalisation.

title.children: France condemns 'barbarity of Islamist terrorism' after school stabbing linked to Israel-Gaza war

image.altText: A young girl riding her bike on a dirt track.

items.synopsis: A velodrome once home to Australian cycling champion Anna Meares is set to play a crucial role in the lead-up to the Brisbane 2032 Olympic Games.

title.children: How Olympian Anna Meares helped turn hometown's crumbling concrete track into international attraction

image.altText: Two young children with blonde hair lie in a hospital bed smiling at the camera holding balloons

items.synopsis: Anya Zuber was cleared from chemotherapy in 2020 at the age of 19 but just 10 days later she was dead. Her family and community have since raised nearly $700,000 for research to help other young people like her.

title.children: From missing Anya's 'seven-second hugs' to raising childhood cancer research funds, NSW family turns grief into hope

image.altText: Tottenham Hotspur manager Ange Postecoglou puts his arm around captain Son Heung-Min.

items.synopsis: Former Socceroos boss Ange Postecoglou is the first coach to win the Premier League's manager of the month award in his first two months in the competition.

title.children: Ange Postecoglou enjoys another first with second straight manager of the month award

image.altText: Yes and No graphic for Voice to Parliament.

items.synopsis: Yes and No camps have run their respective campaign races but if you blinked and missed it, here's what you need to know about each case.

title.children: Making your mind up today? The Yes and No cases for the Voice explained

image.altText: a ballot paper is dropping in a sealed ballot box with a purple lid

items.synopsis: Today, millions will go to the polling booths to cast their votes in the Voice to Parliament referendum. Let's cover the basics before you get into the booth.

title.children: When will we know the results of the Voice vote?

image.altText: An Aboriginal elder looks out of frame, with beautiful native trees in the background.

items.synopsis: It's been 56 years since Australia voted for constitutional change for First Nations people. Elders from Western Australia hope for a similar result in the Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: In 1967, a man holding ballot papers approached Brian Champion in the bush. Now he's preparing to vote 'yes' again

items.synopsis: Here’s what to expect when polls close in the Voice to Parliament referendum and the counting begins tonight.

title.children: How will we know if the Referendum passes or fails?

image.altText: A woman wearing yellow and blue holds a soccer ball to her chest with a window in the background

items.synopsis: Returning to her first professional club Central Coast Mariners, the Matildas forward is ready to answer her critics.

title.children: Kyah Simon wants to banish her Women's World Cup ghosts
